learning_outcomes.description: read and understand articles on contemporary syntactic theory
perform systematic syntactic analysis on sentences and groups of sentences in any language
systematically compare and contrast syntactic structures within and across languages
identify and characterise constructions and properties that provide challenges for contemporary theories
compare and contrast competing analyses of the same data or constructions
understand how superficial differences between languages arise from basic parameter settings
identify similarities across apparently disparate properties within a language
understand the basic enterprise of generative syntax and the extent and limits of syntactic autonomy

assessments.due_date:
WEEK 5 - 25/03/2026 5:00 pm

WEEK 8 - 22/04/2026 5:00 pm

WEEK 11 - 13/05/2026 5:00 pm

Due 5pm, Wed of designated weeks.
assessments.task_description:
Exercise sets will be based on work covered in lectures and/or tutorials, but will often require an extension of the analyses presented in class. These are an opportunity to engage in theoretical analysis, not to simply regurgitate information learned in class or from readings. There are three exercise sets, due in Weeks 5, 8, and 11.

Accuracy of analysis and logical presentation of data and analysis are the key elements assessed.

Students are permitted to work with other students currently enrolled in the course (but NOT with anyone else), in pairs or groups, to solve the problems posed by the assignments. In such cases, each student should note on their submission, the names of the other students with whom they worked. However, each student must individually write up their solutions to the assignment in their own words, to demonstrate their own unique take on and understanding of the material. While collaboration on problem-solving is permitted, collaboration on presentation and wording of submissions is viewed as plagiarism.

STATEMENT ON AI & MT

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: These are to be submitted via Turnitin (through the course Learn/Blackboard site) as PDF documents.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The final exam will feature questions and problems similar to those in the worksheets, covering the material from both lectures and tutorials. It will take place during the Examination Period at the end of semester. Specific details of what you may and may not bring into the examination will be provided well before the end of classes. of semester.

STATEMENT ON AI & MT

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Complete the examination on the exam paper (no additional pages permitted).
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

Weekly two-hour lectures. In these lectures we will develop a theory of syntactic structure piece by piece. Held in 83-S302 on Thursdays from 11-1pm.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08
learning_activities.topic_description: Lectures Weekly two-hour lectures. In these lectures we will develop a theory of syntactic structure piece by piece. Held in 83-S302 on Thursdays from 11-1pm.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 13(02 Mar - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Tutorials

Discussion of problem sets, including alternate solutions, competing analyses, and extensions of analyses, tips and practice problems, and/or deeper exploration of the materials presented in the lectures. Held in 83-S302 on Thursdays from 1-2pm, starting in week 2.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08
